newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya objects to Zaire comments on summit.
newsitem.headline: Kenya objects to Zaire comments on summit.

text.p: Kenya replied sharply to Zaire on Wednesday over claims that a summit on the Great Lakes crisis was organised by English-speaking African leaders dancing to the tune of an unnamed foreign power.
"The claim that the initiative for the meeting is not African smacks of neo-colonial mentality that nothing positive can originate from black Africa," an official Kenyan statement said.
"The truth of the matter is that the summit was convened by President (Daniel arap) Moi of Kenya."

Monday's Nairobi summit, attended by South Africa's Nelson Mandela and eight other leaders, was boycotted by Zaire. The summit called for a peaceful settlement between President Mobutu Sese Seko's government and the rebels who have seized control of eastern Zaire.
Zaire's information minister, Boguo Makele, told Reuters in Kinshasa on Tuesday the summit was part of an Anglo-Saxon plot aiming to destabilise French-speaking Zaire.

"After analysing documents in our possession it seems that the initiative for this meeting is not African and that in effect a foreign power directly implicated in the events in the east is the author of this masquerade," Boguo added.
Zairean ministers have accused the United States of backing Rwanda, which supports the rebels, with logistical help.
The statement, signed by the senior civil servant in the Kenyan information ministry, said French-speaking Rwanda and Cameroon attended the summit and Zaire turned down its invitation.

"Contrary to the impression given by Mr Makele's sentiments, the summit demonstrates that African countries can, should and indeed must generate home-grown solutions to domestic problems and not, so many decades after independence, wait for direction by Western nations," the statement said.
The leaders of Eritrea, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe were the other summit participants.
